escapism and entertainment, especially when a story is specifically aimed 
at children. Ought not a parent scrutinize any movie for possible negative

comment. But why not argue against his point and actually SHOW US how and 
why he's wrong, instead of just (rather assholishly) telling us?

Of course stories can have underlying themes. Hans Christian Anderson and 
Grimm Brothers fairy tales are pretty much known for that. However, most of 
the 'underlying themes' pointed to in Stefan's analysis are just reaching 
and hit-whoring. Elsa killed her parents? Give me a fucking break. If this 
is the story Stefan wants to read or watch on TV, why not just go read or 
watch the movie version of Oedipus? One doesn't have to infect one story 
with the themes of a completely different story in order to wrench from it 
some kind of provocative analysis which will impress college kids. I love a 
good, provocative analysis as much as the next guy, but not if you're just 
trying to shove the square pegs of the plot and themes in question through 
the round holes of your own twisted worldview and agenda. I found this to 
be more revealing of how Stefan's own mind works rather than a serious 
reflection on Disney's Frozen.

Excellent, and well-enacted analysis.

The only thing I disagree with is the hard separation of the supposedly 
reptilian urge to perpetuate genes and the rational pursuit of love as 
virtue.

I don't believe there is a clear separation between the cognitive and the 
biological. It seems to me that what is beneficial to us as social beings 
is also served by our biology. However, nature only lends a helping hand - 
some things we must do for ourselves. And so I think that human sex is a 
physical, emotional and cognitive act all at the same time and one of the 
natural products is bonding between the couple. This is more than reptilian 
and does not arise from psychological dysfunction but from normal human 
function. And so whatever else nature gives us in terms of granting and 
gratifying sexual urges, it also helps us to be virtuous. But, certainly, 
nature is not enough.

When considering the necessity of cultivating virtue, I like the Ancient 
Greek understanding which identifies a human moral faculty as inherent as 
every other human faculty (e.g. the capacity to learn language.) However, 
the Greeks understood that like all such capacities it needs to be trained 
in order to reach its full potential. I don't think we have a reptilian 
nature that we need to escape, but a human nature that we need to nurture 
and perfect. The reptilian for a human being IS dysfunction.

I often find myself in discussions with people who want to tell me about 
reptiles and ducks and bonobos and chimpanzees and the like as if this will 
help me to understand myself better. I fear these comparisons are more 
likely to mislead than inform. Why? Because I am none of these things and 
think the dissimilarities probably make the similarities irrelevant.  ﻿

A couple observations.  I enjoy this video as an intellectual exercise in 
finding the correlations in allegory.  It only works if you ask yourself 
where we would find people in similar situations in the real world.  So, a 
child being shut-in by her parents because she is dangerous; that's a 
situation you would probably only see in the case of a child with 
psychological problems.  If you frame it in that way, then almost every 
observation is on-point.  

On the other hand, it does kind of take the fun out of fairy tales when you 
do that.  I also don't think any of these things are the actual intended 
meaning of the story.  Like J.R.R. Tolkien said; don't mistake 
applicability for allegory.  

I don't give the Disney writers that much credit for subtlety.﻿

All Hollywood movies have a moment of "divine intervention" written into 
their scripts, and that's why I believe the people running the film 
business are more interested in promoting spirituality or religion as a 
life choice.

When millions of dollars are available to promote the "artistic" side of an 
individual, don't be surprised if that individual turns out to have 
personal motives at heart. Both George Lucas and Steven Spielberg have 
taken liberties with the riches thrown at them to make their films. We can 
see their personal insecurities and political agendas on screen.

The new Star Wars films (Episodes 1-3) were a big let down, but only 
because Lucas couldn't see the benefit of the inventiveness he employed in 
the 1970s, and the realism that got myself and all my schoolmates building 
toy spaceships and robots.

Stephen Spielberg can't seem to make a sci-fi film without injecting a bit 
of spiritualism into it. Close Encounters was no exception - the aliens 
"communicated" with humans telepathically. Minority Report was based on the 
idea that humans could be genetically grown to "telepathically" see the 
future.

This is all either lazy, or intentional script-writing. I imagine it is a 
mix of both, but I accuse Hollywood of keeping us all dumb. I accuse 
Hollywood of regurgitating the same film format wrapped in different 
wallpaper just because most of us are too dumb to notice.

And dare I add - I think the government are in on this too!﻿

Just saw the movie, and watched this.....The first half of this analysis 
was pretty good, if a bit focused on only one of many possible messages in 
the movie .
But you got sort of blurry at the end. Anna doesn't thaw her sisters frozen 
heart. She thaws her own, not through true love as she loved her sister all 
along, but by doing the first truly unselfish thing in her life for her 
sister, or anyone for that matter. The fact that her body becomes 
completely frozen is irrelevant because it does not indicate death- being 
frozen is life in this movie. What becoming fully frozen, I think is meant 
to signify, is growing up. And thawing again is accepting both the child 
and adult in one's psyche. At least this one way to interpret it. At any 
rate, Anna doesn't die, do that part of your analysis is off. 

It's weird that you quibble about the thawing ice disobeying the laws of 
physics, because, guess what? I've never obeys the laws of physics in this 
movie. Seems an odd spot to have noticed this.

And speaking of jot noticing things, you mention that this movie suggests 
that women instantly acquire skills, but there's an entire mountain 
climbing sequence that demonstrates that she doesn't have the skills that 
Kristoff has, not even close. And, sure she saves his life twice, but 
you're discounting the fact that it was her amateurish blundering and 
refusal to accept reality ( that she sent capable of going off alone to 
fund her sister towards evening in a ball gown) that endangers his life in 
the first place. In her defense, she had no idea that her sister was going 
to cause winter for miles around, or out walk a horse, when she set out, 
so, there's that. 
For balance's sake, I just wish they had had Elsa thaw out hans' heart at 
the end, instead of sending him back shamed to his toxic family. That bit 
shows a cruel streak in the sisters. After all, the sisters recognize that 
his heart is frozen, they announce it﻿

This hour diatribe seems to miss the point of watching an entertaining 
movie.  All science fiction/fantasy deals with alternate physics that does 
not exist in the real world.  The audience is willing to suspend disbelief 
to watch an entertaining story.  If all stories only dealt with things that 
could be real (according to our current understanding) then we would have 
far less variety of things available to watch.  

Therefor magic does not represent madness, but is sometimes a metaphor for 
something else, such as Elsa having to hide her identity, in the closet 
sort of speak, and then later "come out."  

Magic also represents our desire for empowerment, i.e. to be able to do 
more than we are currently capable.  However, this desire to do more 
actually advances us a species.   Some things that would have seemed almost 
magical in the world of Star Trek 50 years ago have come into existence, or 
may yet still come to pass.﻿

future is in jeopardy just when I figured out what it is going to be.

Just as a side note, I just wanted say (at the risk of sounding like a 
dick, apologies) that the 10,000 hour rule is to achieve mastery in a 
discipline. Malcolm Gladwell himself said how the concept gets 
misconstrued. It has actually been researched that to pick up a new habit 
and become decent in a discipline only requires about 20 hours of effort. 
The 10,000 hours thing is mostly about finding the appropriate challenge 
for your skill level, which is the most time consuming part of the process, 
and it can be shortened if the process is streamlined. People have gone 
from novice to grand master chess players in 4,000 hours practice using 
online chess because the matchmaking algorithms place players against 
opponents of similar skill level. You don't get that in sports or martial 
arts or solitary pursuits so much, so it takes longer to advance in skill.

I actually think the frozen heart thing was very insightful, I'll explain:

Elsa doesn't have a frozen heart because she's actually just completely 
insane. Her insanity and her careless outbursts have frozen Annas heart. 
Keep in mind Elsa did not intend to hurt Anna and wasn't able to recognize 
the consequences of her actions.

Anna is infected by Elsa's madness, but it has struck her heart instead of 
her head. Her heart is frozen rendering her all but incapable of love, 
eventually she will die a symbolic death of permanent invincible loneliness 
when her heart completely freezes.

Annas' self sacrifice thaws Annas' heart, because ultimately your choices 
and your actions are the final say in what kind of person you will be, and 
can overcome the prejudices imparted to you by others. It is important that 
she sacrificed herself for her sister because it was an act of true love, 
not lust.

Stefan, you claim 'magic' is synonymous with delusion, fantasy, 
irrationality and craziness. While that can often be the case, magic can 
also be defined as phenomena observed or experienced by some people (but 
not necessarily everyone) which have not yet been adequately explained 
scientifically (rationally).

Just as humans are prone to imagining magical phenomena where there is 
none, it is JUST AS TRUE that humans are prone to explaining away magical 
(ie unexplained, but real) phenomena using seemingly rational but wholly 
inappropriate scientific explanations which do not really *explain* the 
phenomena in question at all.

Human experience has always been increasing at a faster rate than science 
(rationality) can explain or account for. The concept of 'magic' can be 
thought of NOT so much as an explanation, but rather as a placeholder until 
an suitable explanation can be figured out based on knowledge or data which 
we do not yet posses.

It is not 'magic' that is at fault here, it is scientists who incorrectly 
define magic as a *explanation* rather than as a *placeholder in lieu of an 
explanation* who are at fault here. When scientists dismiss 'magic' what 
they are often doing is just refusing to admit they don't have an adequate 
explanation either. Or you could say that when scientists come up with a 
crappy explanation which not really explain the phenomena, they like to 
point to a 'magical' explanation and say "Hey, at least our explanation is 
better than that!" .... but 'magic' is not an explanation, it is a 
placeholder for an explanation in the absence of enough data and knowledge.

In many ways to call a genuinely unusual phenomenon 'magic' is more 
accurate (more scientific) than to insist it must have been the product of 
some well established scientific process or mechanism, even when the data 
does not really fit.

At least the term 'magic' leaves the door open for further enquiry and a 
possible rational / scientific explanation in the future. But once you 
incorrectly define 'magical' (ie unusual) phenomena in mundane terms you 
close that door forever.

The modern world is full of wonderful and terrifying observations of 
'magical phenomena' which have been effectively sealed off and quarantined 
by the establishment scientific community, which has defined them as 
mundane examples of ordinary science and nothing we should concern 
ourselves with. Move along now.....

An incorrect scientific explanation is by far the worst example of a 
'superstition', and the hardest to budge once it is in place.

The opposite of superstition, rationality and delusion is NOT the claims 
made by the scientific community. They are (with VERY FEW exceptions) just 
priests in white lab coats, that's all.﻿

Disagree that magic is always about craziness: totally disagree (it can be 
about this, but not always). I'd go with Joesph Campbell on this, "Myth is 
the secret opening through which the inexhaustible energies of the cosmos 
pour into human cultural manifestation. Religions, philosophies, arts, the 
social forms of primitive and historic man, prime discoveries in science 
and technology, the very dreams that blister sleep, boil up from the basic, 
magic ring of myth."

Yes, as with all things, there is a downside to creativity, and that is why 
"religion" is on the list above. But prior to Darwin, what were people to 
think? Gods were a creative way of addressing obviously important issues 
with no explanation (like the complex design of living beings). 

Star Trek has inspired many technologists, and the line between high 
technology and magic is very thin, as Clarke pointed out. Star Trek too is 
mythology.

My own interpretation of the movie? Else's magic represents the creativity 
and independence within all of us. The repression by her parents is the 
surface values, materialism, and statism that are threatened by her inner 
power of being who she really is -- a free and creative being. Her parents 
shaming her magic, is the attempt to make her conform to social values, 
religion, etc.. Her sister represents those who are "freedom kin" whose 
love and recognition help her to manifest her creativity in a positive 
manner, rather than through the twisted process of rigid social systems 
that don't honor individuality, or the twisted anger of having been shamed 
for being herself.

All that said, I think Stef makes some very interesting points along the 
way... there are a lot of distorted concepts that are common to Hollywood 
plots tarnishing the inspiring core story of individuation. The men 
knocking stuff, for example, I also found disgusting.

I also agree that, like most good myths, this can be interpreted on many 
layers: that is the magic of them... you can read into them what you want 
and allow them to reflect your values: mirrors to your own rumination.﻿

contribute when I can, but I think you are kind of off on this one. I can 
see that you have worked really hard to associate fantasy with mental 
illness, then to build your narrative from there. I however would point out 
that "magic" and fantasy have both been used as literary foils for... well 
since the beginning of human interaction. The unknown and forbidden (as 
literary magic usually is) excites the imagination, and draws the listener 
into the story. It makes the story more remarkable. Magic and fantasy 
allows you to share moral, ethical, and even spiritual concepts free from 
the burden of human prejudice. I know you have a hard-on hatred of all 
things fantastic, but for those people stuck on the lower levels of 
Maslow's hierarchy of needs, fantasy and the "magic" it creates is 
sometimes their only recreation, their only escape. And whether you want to 
believe it or not, escape is important. ﻿

As a writer, there's typically an (1) intended message within one's work. 
Cynically, you could say that most stories are a form of propaganda. 
There's also sometimes (2) meaning that can seep into a writer's work, most 
of the time repetitively throughout many works which could be construed as 
the writer's 'voice'. And then there's the (3) meaning that can be derived 
from an artist's work that they never intended, that the audience, reader, 
or viewer pieces together him or herself, which tells us more about the 
observer than the artist.

While you make some valid points here - for instance the reason audience 
members like to escape into a magical problems-are-quickly-solved world, 
the draw of the 'chosen one' story trope of which I also tire - don't you 
think there's a fair amount of number 3 going on here?

Whenever anyone looks deeply into something relatively simple, I'm reminded 
of Martin Lawrence's character from Boomerang talking about the invention 
of the game of pool. He posits that the game is an exercise in the White 
Ball knocking all the colored balls off the earth (green felt table) one by 
one, until the final Black Ball is all that remains. The simplicity of the 
game of pool (or billiards for you English folk) allows for that 
interpretation I suppose; that may have been the intent of the inventor 
from the beginning. But you have to want to see it to see it.

I think you're giving the writer(s) of Frozen *way* more credit than I.﻿

To those complaining that his analysis is stupid because the filmmakers 
couldn't possibly have put that much thought into it: An intended 
implication means the same thing as an unintended one to the observer. 
There's an entire school of media criticism that posits that authorial 
intent is actually meaningless when criticizing their work. What is being 
described here are deeply-held cultural views that are perpetuated by our 
media. The author need not even be aware of the implications of their work. 
One of the jobs of an author is to avoid unintended implications, but even 
if an author doesn't mean to create a story with a hidden meaning (like 
Tolkein), those meanings are still there because what the author creates is 
a product of himself (thus any criticism of Tolkein's work which talks 
about their being an anti-industrialization meaning in The Lord of the 
Rings, or even a Christian one, are both equally valid). A child may not be 
able to intellectualize what he or she is seeing, but it still affects 
their view--same for an adult who never learned to put their entertainment 
in context. And the critic, like the author, while striving for the goal of 
objectivity, cannot completely remove himself from his criticism.﻿

Clearly you misunderstand what's being presented. These "conspiracy" 
theories that stefan is "making up" aren't for the intellectual adult mind, 
they're targeted at very young audiences because they soak up everything 
shown and given to them at a rate that puts all adults to shame.

Children learn and comprehend multitudes faster than adults ever could, 
because their brains are still growing and fluid, they haven't settled into 
the shape and form that adulthood brings.

Kids not getting and understanding these things is by design. If your child 
steals a cookie and you smack or spank them, they don't necessarily 
understand why you punish them in such a way, but they do understand 
consequence of action.

If a very young child is exposed to media and social conditioning telling 
them that marriage is a living hell, say by having dysfunctional parents, 
or parents who never say they love eachother or get along very often in 
front of the child or talk about love dying or fading with time, they will 
subconsciously associate love and marriage with a gradual degradation of 
happiness, not wanting any part of it.

They won't fully understand why until later in their lives by hindsight and 
insight.

As adults, we can look at our childhoods in retrospect, deduce why we feel 
certain ways about certain things.

To end, the only full family unit we see in Frozen is the royal family, as 
Stefan points out, and they're ashamed of their children, never get along 
all that well, are abusive and neglectful, and ignorant of the finer points 
of parenthood and in general common sense.

The only other family we hear about is Hans's, and that's also made out to 
be horrible and something nobody would want.

Meanwhile everyone else seems normal, the non full family units, everyone 
who isn't married with children, are shown to be more content than the 
families.

Children will not understand why they don't see any functioning familial 
unit, but they will see and subconsciously associate a full committed 
family with negative things.

If a child only ever sees their parents fighting, they will subconsciously 
associate marriage, love, and being a family with misery. The same way that 
very young girls seeing this movie will learn to subconsciously associate 
well off, charming, and handsome boys and young men with evil and deceit, 
betrayal and selfish lies.

This movie, and by extension, media like it, is the way it is by

  My understanding of "begging the question", despite the name, is a 
logical fallacy about a proposed statement of fact. The proof of the fact 
just assumes the fact is true in the first place.  "Magic is real, because 
magic is the very basis of reality" would be circular and "begging the 
question".
  Adrian is proposing a question. "Begging the question" fallacies could 
come up in the answering of the question, but aren't in the question 
itself.

'Is magic an escape from reality or a way to embrace the complete fullness 
of reality through a deeper mystical understanding of our place within the 
greater purposeful eternal context of God?' Thats blatantly begging the 
question.
